Award.AwardTitle: TIP: Transforming Computer Science Education using 'upside down' Curriculum, Course-embedded projects, Integration with other STEM disciplines, and Peer Mentors

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Targeted Infusion Project at Fisk University seeks to transform computer science teaching through an innovative computer science curriculum and pedagogical techniques that will create awareness, interest and success in computer science, ultimately contributing to the workforce needs of the U.S. A central feature of this project is to turn the computer science curriculum "upside down", so that students will use the latest computer science tools and techniques to develop real-life and relevant products in their introductory courses. This is in contrast to the traditional curriculum, where exciting features are introduced in sophomore or junior years, which is often too late to retain students in the major. Project objectives are to: introduce computational thinking in computer science courses for non-majors; introduce appealing tools in introductory courses for computer science majors, and foster their use in course-embedded projects; integrate computing into targeted mathematics and physics cognate courses in the computer science major pathway; and utilize peer mentoring to foster deeper learning of computer science in targeted computer science, mathematics, and physics courses.

The involvement of computer science faculty in addition to mathematics and physics faculty in efforts to transform the computer science curriculum at Fisk University suggests that project impact will extend across multiple disciplines. The project will broaden the participation of currently underrepresented individuals in the computer science and computational workforce. Furthermore, faculty development, mentor training, and the enhancement of pedagogical techniques will promote sustained and continuous improvements of the computer science curriculum and its integration with other relevant disciplines. Project activities include broad dissemination efforts to increase public computer science literacy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This TIP Award to  Fisk University includes a four-objective plan to innovate the curriculum and the pedagogies employed in the teaching and learning of computer science (CS) in order to create awareness, interest and success in CS as a discipline, increase the number of women and under-represented minorities in CS as majors, and increase the number from Fisk who go on to careers or to advanced study in CS. To achieve these overall goals, we have outlined four objectives:

Objective 1 - Computational Thinking in CS courses for non-majors: Modify the CS curriculum for non-majors by revising the introductory CS course (CS 100; 3hr credit) to include computational thinking, and add two one-credit hour courses on Mobile Apps and on Web Apps.

  • CS100 – Introduction to Computing. In this existing three- credit hour course, which was the only CS course currently available to non-majors, students were trained in collaborative tools, cloud-based resources, computational thinking, and writing scripts in order to develop real life applications. 
  • CS106– Introduction to Mobile Apps. A new introductory course (1 credit hour) in mobile apps was created. The course was designed for non-majors and there is no prerequisite. Students used graphical tools (e.g., AppInventor) or HTML5/CSS/JavaScript to develop their mobile apps. This course attracted computer proficient students from other majors (e.g. Biology and Psychology). 
  • CS108 – Introduction to Web Apps. A new introductory course (1 credit hour) in developing web apps was created. The latest cloud-based services and collaborative tools were used in developing projects related to real life applications.  

Objective 2 - Appealing Tools in Introductory Courses: Introduce CS tools perceived as ‘relevant’ by students in introductory CS courses on the major pathway (specifically CS 110 - Introduction to Computer Science --- Structured Programming, CSCI 120 - Object Orientation, and CSCI 241 - Data Structures and Algorithms) and foster use of these tools in course-embedded student-engaged projects and faculty-student mentored summer research projects.

333% increase in CSCI 110 enrollment

Fifty (50) students enrolled in CSCI 110 in Fall 2015, which is 333% increase (average of 5 years before the grant)

233% increase in CSCI 120 enrollment

Twenty (20) students enrolled in CSCI 120 in Spring 2016, which is 233% increase (average of 5 years before the grant).

250% increase in CSCI 241 enrollment

Fourteen (14) students enrolled in CSCI 241 in Fall 2015, which is 250% increase (average of 5 years before the grant)

 

Objective 3 - Computing in Cognate Courses: Introduce computational thinking in cognate courses required for CS majors, namely Mathematics and Physics, in order to sustain the impact of computational thinking across the curriculum. In these courses, students learnt new computing techniques and terminologies and how to apply them. This reduced the levels of computing unfamiliarity should they take computing courses or encounter software code in their summer research or internships.  To develop common assignments across CS, Mathematics and Physics, the same constructs and programs across the curriculum were developed. 

Objective 4 - Peer Mentors (PM): Utilize peer mentoring/coaching to foster deeper learning of CS in CSCI110/120/241 and in cognate courses, such as Math101/Math110/Math120 and Physics 130/140, and to serve as ‘coaches’ in course-assigned projects. 

  • Peer mentors were selected based on their academic excellence, prior experience, and teacher recommendation.
  • Peer mentors were given mandatory training sessions in the beginning of semester
  • The meeting times and schedule were documented and shared with all potential students and faculty advisors.
  • Time sheets and logs were submitted to the Office of Academic Excellence and Student Performance (AESP).
  • The AESP office ensured the quality of peer-mentoring support and payment schedule.
  • Peer mentoring provided necessary support and guidance to students experiencing difficulties in their courses.
  • Peer mentors met with the course faculty weekly to receive feedback and additional input about the learning goals for the students. Included in the discussion was how to individualize the support for students who were at different places in their understanding and mastery of course materials.

Students obtained prestigious internships in software engineering (e.g., Google, Apple, Microsoft) and competitive full-time job offers. The faculty-mentored summer research and course projects were presented at National (e.g., NCUR) and regional conferences, as well as at Annual Fisk Research Symposium.
